description: From Middle English mousere (“a hunter of mice”), equivalent to mouse +‎ -er. The “moustache” sense is apparently an extended usage (i.e., a cat’s whiskers, jocularly transferred to human beings), possibly with influence from moustache.

entries.meaning: A cat that catches mice, kept specifically for the purpose. [from 15th c.]

examples: He was a pretty man, well upstanding, with great shoulders on him and his hair was fair and fine and he had a broad brow and a gey bit coulter of a nose and he twisted his mouser ends up with wax like that creature the German Kaiser […].
